body.p:
Methinks I hear you say what
a miserable correspondent my friend has become
or has the scythe of time ? down her
energies or has absence rendered her indifferent
to her old friends. Neither kind sir, but Sickness
which is beyond our control has made me a delin
quent in every thing but sincerity. I have had many
of my immediate family confined to the bed with sickness
& have been ill myself & have continued to feel its
debilitating influence. But as Mrs Chick says in Dombey
“I must make an effort” or my friends will lay me
aside as a thing that has been! In truth I begin to
think Charleston does not agree with me spiritually or
bodily in a city ones thoughts turn naturally into the
channels in which flows the thoughts of those around them
In the country what one hears & sees suggests entirely dif
ferent mediations The universal harmony of nature
stills our fretted passions all the eye rests on speaks
of infinite wisdom & providential care & we feel
that we can commune with nature & with natures
God with more deep devotion & more pious faith
my Son has been confined for a month & required
my sole attendance & as Sarah ? was absent I had
every thing devolving on myself. My daughter has
returned & although not well is much improved &
Philip is again at his business. So “Richard is himself
again”

you have had my friend & cousin A Moise with you he
wrote you were pleased to name me in warm terms
of friendship for which accept my thanks. The approba
tion of the world pleasant but a thousand times
more so is the commendation of an enlightened & intelligent
friend — I heard with deep regret that my friend R Hart had
been ill, tender her my warmest sympathies tell her
I will write as soon as I can, without the form of a reply
to my last. I often wish I could in more powerful language
than profession, manifest my deep affection for that pure
& meritorious couple! but that could jade makes me
niggard in all but affection. Adversity is a shrewd
taskmistress, a mighty moral leveller, how it teaches us to appre-
ciate kindness & to discover friends where we had only
discerned inferiors! It is the Jewel shiek out of the
ugliness & venom of the heart. I have not tasted of
the draught as deeply as many more deserving but
sufficiently so to value those friends who love me
for the little merit I posses & not for the gilding
that adorns the picture! I am happy in writing that
my sister is enjoying good health after so much of
bodily & mental suffering. She has not yet recovered
her spirits her deep seated affection for our departed
brother, still renders her indifferent to society in fact
it is so painful for her even to come & pass a day
with me that except in sickness I do not eseach?
it the full check & the sparkling eye of early youth do
not tell their tale of suffering like the worn fea-
tures of after years ? although Sis is not old yet

sorrow has left its withering influence on her mind!
Well Mr. Tobias has another daughter engaged Priscilla
the devotee to forms & ceremonies has o'er leaped them
all! & engaged herself to L Myers such are the inconsisten
cies of human beings; at her time of life there is not the
excuse of passion subduing reason & I expect there was
more matter than mind, in the compact which
holds them together. She represents him par excellen
ce as the man of piety & love for a religion. She knows
nothing of this is (entre nous) as I am intimate with
the family & fond of them & would not willingly hurt
their feelings. I do hope & pray that the Holy Shrine
of Home, which should be wreathed with blossoms
may not be heaped with ice & the only garland which
renders it attractive, beaten out of cold & sordid gold
I presume among the ? you have heard of the application
we have had to fill the place of our valued minister
from his own & the Rabbi Guiste's recommendation he is
par parenthese the very beau ideal of all that hum-
an desire could covet but I am perfectly content
with the one we have & desire no change — still
I remain quiet as if I am not so small a fish as to move
among my adversaries without threatening the water
If you desire further information relative to this ?
of the 19th century I will give it you in my next
I do pray that if he comes among us he will inspire
more zeal than now exists among the Jews of Charles
-ton it seems to me they aim at doing the least
possible good in the longest possible time.

my remarks are not to be handed about as a relish for
the tea table for I aim at being good, but by some
unfortunate propensity I sometimes forget the character
I wish to be & shew the one I am & a little of the
venom of frail nature will shew itself although
regret comes as soon as it is expressed & therefore
I am more cautious in society than in writing. For
custom has placed a padlock on the lips of women
of which society keeps the key & therefore we must not
say all we feel or think. My family both white & coloured
seem to suffer by the change from Georgia to Carolina
I hope after this summer their health will be better
my own health has been delicate all summer & I
crave change of air & scene in fact I require repose of
mind & body for the duties which devolve on me are
no sincere I assure you. I have a great big ? of
hope which sustains me & hope on hope ever is my
motto & the world I suppose think my path should
with Rose leaves & as appearances are the current
coin of the World I watch over them as the miser
watches his hoarded gold, while scribbling this I have
had so many interruptions that I must close
an ? after assuring you of the regards
of family & the sincerity of your friend.
